title: No Proof Hamas Routinely Stole U.N. Aid, Israeli Military Officials Say
summary: Israel has long restricted or completely blocked aid to Gaza on the argument that Hamas steals it to use as a weapon of control over the population.

title: How Seeking Food in Gaza Has Become So Deadly
summary: Hundreds of Palestinians have been killed over the past month near aid hubs set up under a new Israeli-backed system, according to Gaza health officials.

title: From Epstein to Obama, Trump’s Washington Is Consumed by Competing Conspiracies
summary: President Trump is trying to divert attention from the Epstein conspiracy theory with new-and-improved one about Barack Obama and treason.

title: A Clash Over a Promotion Puts Hegseth at Odds With His Generals
summary: Suspicions about leaks and a mistrust of senior military officers have defined much of the defense secretary’s first six months on the job.

title: A Kennedy Toils in Mississippi, Tracing His Grandfather’s Path
summary: Joe Kennedy III, the grandson of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, says there is work to do in red states. He also has a few things to say about his uncle, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

title: This Democrat Wants Cognitive Standards in Congress. Her Colleagues Disagree.
summary: Representative Marie Gluesenkamp Perez says age-related cognitive decline among elected officials is a major issue for voters.

title: In Russia, Corruption Cases Follow Battlefield Failures
summary: Officials in three of the five Russian regions bordering Ukraine have been accused of embezzling funds for border defenses.

title: New Reports on Russian Interference Show Trump’s Claims on Obama Are Overblown
summary: The administration’s claims are overblown, but newly declassified information provides some messy details about a January 2017 intelligence assessment of Moscow’s election interference.

title: He Read (at Least) 3,599 Books in His Lifetime. Now Anyone Can See His List.
summary: After Dan Pelzer died this month at 92, his children uploaded the handwritten reading list to what-dan-read.com, hoping to inspire readers everywhere.

title: How Hulk Hogan Leg-Dropped the Digital Media Industry
summary: His lawsuit over a leaked sex tape bankrupted Gawker Media — and helped inspire the American right’s ongoing war on the press.

title: Harvard’s Leader, Penny Pritzker, Faces Intense Scrutiny in Trump Fight
summary: As Harvard and the government negotiate to end a conflict with billions of dollars on the line, some ask whether Penny Pritzker, the head of the school’s governing board, should step down.

title: States Look to Europe to Improve U.S. Prison Conditions
summary: States of all political stripes, including Oklahoma, North Dakota and Massachusetts, have sent officials to tour prisons in Germany in search of ways to improve conditions for American inmates.

title: A Judge Gave a One-Word Answer. It Torpedoed the Etan Patz Case.
summary: After an appeals court overturned a conviction, prosecutors must decide whether to retry a man in the notorious 1979 child killing for a third time.

title: Plastic Turf Fields Are Taking Over America
summary: The debate over whether to install turf over grass fields has become a referendum on sports, health, the environment and the use of scarce public resources.

title: CBS: Caving. Bowing. Scraping.
summary: Don’t take on satirists — they always get the last laugh.

title: Trump Isn’t Getting Rid of Chaos at the Border. He’s Redistributing It.
summary: “The Opinions” round table discusses the president’s immigration policies and the emerging resistance to it.

title: Little Victories
summary: We tend to confine our parties to milestones and cultural events, but there are countless micro-occasions worthy of commemorating.

title: Military Clash Between Thailand and Cambodia Expands Along Shared Border
summary: The deadliest conflict between the two nations in 14 years, now in its third day, extended to provinces about 200 miles south of where clashes first began.

title: Taiwan Votes in Recall Campaign That Tests China’s Nerves
summary: An unprecedented recall vote could hand President Lai Ching-te more power by ousting legislative opponents. It could also prompt a response from China.

title: Removal of Castro and Guevara Statues Ignites Outcry in Mexico City
summary: The Cuban Revolution leaders joined forces in Mexico in 1955. A local mayor removed a memorial to them, drawing protests and condemnation from Mexico’s highest office.
